update.description:
Here's a fun bug:

Open up Gazebo on default branch. Point your `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` environment variable to a folder that is readable only by root, or `chmod` something that's already on your `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` so that it's only readable by `root`. Then start Gazebo. It will crash with a message like:
```
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::filesystem::filesystem_error'
  what():  boost::filesystem::status: Permission denied: "/home/jackie/gazebo_models/foo/model.config"
```

I discovered this bug working on the building editor. Some users had folders in their home folder that were owned by root (even worse, a hidden folder, .dbus). The home folder seems like a reasonable default location to leave models, but the problem arose when I tried to add the home folder to the paths displayed in `InsertModelWidget` (the Qt widget that shows the "Insert Model" tab).

This pull request catches the issue by first checking if the user has permission to access a directory before attempting to read it into the Insert Model tab.
update.title: Bugfix for permission denied crash

content.raw: Nice work! just a little note, not for this time (I'm happy with the current state), but for the next one: ideally, if the different tests (cases in this file) are not interdependent, they should go into different test cases and every of one the test cases should have a descriptive name: AccessToRestrictedParent, AccessToPermittedPath, ... This will help to interpret the error since all the tests run, and you have a clear idea about which of them are failing.
content.html: Nice work! just a little note, not for this time (I'm happy with the current state), but for the next one: ideally, if the different tests (cases in this file) are not interdependent, they should go into different test cases and every of one the test cases should have a descriptive name: AccessToRestrictedParent, AccessToPermittedPath, ... This will help to interpret the error since all the tests run, and you have a clear idea about which of them are failing.

content.raw: I have finished the integration test, insert_model.cc. It is a Qtest that uses a try/catch statement around functions that may read inaccessible folders, and calls QFAIL in the catch blocks. I also added a data structure and a function to InsertModelWidget to keep track of files that have been added to the graphical FileTreeWidget. I use it in the test to verify if the desired path has been added to the FileTreeWidget. This feature might not be necessary, however. Let me know what you all think.
content.html: I have finished the integration test, insert_model.cc. It is a Qtest that uses a try/catch statement around functions that may read inaccessible folders, and calls QFAIL in the catch blocks. I also added a data structure and a function to InsertModelWidget to keep track of files that have been added to the graphical FileTreeWidget. I use it in the test to verify if the desired path has been added to the FileTreeWidget. This feature might not be necessary, however. Let me know what you all think.

content.raw: I think I can easily make an integration test that is a QTest and use gz_build_qt_tests macro to build. The only thing is that I won't be able to use QTest's ASSERT_NO_THROW macro as Jose suggested. Maybe I can find the equivalent in QTest, however.
content.html: I think I can easily make an integration test that is a QTest and use gz_build_qt_tests macro to build. The only thing is that I won't be able to use QTest's ASSERT_NO_THROW macro as Jose suggested. Maybe I can find the equivalent in QTest, however.

content.html: All of our gui tests use QTest. Is that an option here?

content.raw:
it is interesting that there are no existing integration tests that depend on `gazebo::gui` and therefore Qt. Is there a particular reason for this? I want to make a test that has Qt objects (such as MainWindow) but uses GTest instead of QTest, this is OK, right?

err, do I have to fiddle with GazeboTestUtils.cmake to make this work? Maybe fill in the `gz_build_display_tests` macro?
content.html:
it is interesting that there are no existing integration tests that depend on gazebo::gui and therefore Qt. Is there a particular reason for this? I want to make a test that has Qt objects (such as MainWindow) but uses GTest instead of QTest, this is OK, right?

err, do I have to fiddle with GazeboTestUtils.cmake to make this work? Maybe fill in the gz_build_display_tests macro?

content.raw:
*How should I use the test framework to check for when Gazebo crashes? Should I have try/catch statements in the test my test and fail the test in catch statements (since it means an exception went through)?*

If the software crashes due to an exception, maybe we can use here the `ASSERT_NO_THROW` from gtest.

*Should this be an InsertModelWidget unit test or should it be an integration test?*

Strictly speaking in terms of testing, that would fit better as an integration (several subsystems are being tested at the same time) than as a unit. To build a unit test we should make a non trivial work of mock and stubs. I also tend to consider that all testing which involves the X subsystem fall under a different category and not unit tests. Definitions on unit testing usually include the need of being run fast.

*Not really a question, more of a statement: I can easily change the permissions of a file using Boost, though it looks like I can't change the owner, so that case will not be taken care of.*

I would not expect gazebo (or any other software) to touch any of permission unless it explicitly warn me about that.
content.html:
How should I use the test framework to check for when Gazebo crashes? Should I have try/catch statements in the test my test and fail the test in catch statements (since it means an exception went through)?

If the software crashes due to an exception, maybe we can use here the ASSERT_NO_THROW from gtest.

Should this be an InsertModelWidget unit test or should it be an integration test?

Strictly speaking in terms of testing, that would fit better as an integration (several subsystems are being tested at the same time) than as a unit. To build a unit test we should make a non trivial work of mock and stubs. I also tend to consider that all testing which involves the X subsystem fall under a different category and not unit tests. Definitions on unit testing usually include the need of being run fast.

Not really a question, more of a statement: I can easily change the permissions of a file using Boost, though it looks like I can't change the owner, so that case will not be taken care of.

I would not expect gazebo (or any other software) to touch any of permission unless it explicitly warn me about that.

content.raw:
Couple of questions about how to best implement the test.

How should I use the test framework to check for when Gazebo crashes? Should I have try/catch statements in the test my test and fail the test in catch statements (since it means an exception went through)?

I could also check what items made it into the InsertModelWidget. Is there a way of doing this without adding public accessors to InsertModelWidget?

Should this be an InsertModelWidget unit test or should it be an integration test?

Not really a question, more of a statement: I can easily change the permissions of a file using Boost, though it looks like I can't change the owner, so that case will not be taken care of.
content.html:
Couple of questions about how to best implement the test.

How should I use the test framework to check for when Gazebo crashes? Should I have try/catch statements in the test my test and fail the test in catch statements (since it means an exception went through)?

I could also check what items made it into the InsertModelWidget. Is there a way of doing this without adding public accessors to InsertModelWidget?

Should this be an InsertModelWidget unit test or should it be an integration test?

Not really a question, more of a statement: I can easily change the permissions of a file using Boost, though it looks like I can't change the owner, so that case will not be taken care of.

content.raw: You can move this line out of the try/catch block.
content.html: You can move this line out of the try/catch block.

content.raw: A leading underscore should be use only for function parameters.
content.html: A leading underscore should be use only for function parameters.

content.raw: Can you write a test for this, and update the changelog?
content.html: Can you write a test for this, and update the changelog?

update.description:
Here's a fun bug:

Open up Gazebo on default branch. Point your `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` environment variable to a folder that is readable only by root, or `chmod` something that's already on your `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` so that it's only readable by `root`. Then start Gazebo. It will crash with a message like:
```
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::filesystem::filesystem_error'
  what():  boost::filesystem::status: Permission denied: "/home/jackie/gazebo_models/foo/model.config"
```

I discovered this bug working on the building editor. Some users had folders in their home folder that were owned by root (even worse, a hidden folder, .dbus). The home folder seems like a reasonable default location to leave models, but the problem arose when I tried to add the home folder to the paths displayed in `InsertModelWidget` (the Qt widget that shows the "Insert Model" tab).

This pull request catches the issue by first checking if the user has permission to access a directory before attempting to read it into the Insert Model tab.
update.title: Bugfix for permission denied crash

content.raw: thanks Jose, it looks like the best approach. I'm going to remove a problematic gzlog (line 326), clean up a tiny bit and merge it.
content.html: thanks Jose, it looks like the best approach. I'm going to remove a problematic gzlog (line 326), clean up a tiny bit and merge it.

content.raw:
Thanks Jackie. I like this much more. Seems like the exists call is not enough to detect all the failing cases:

```
jrivero@nium build $ GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH="/root" gazebo
QInotifyFileSystemWatcherEngine::addPaths: inotify_add_watch failed: Permission denied
QFileSystemWatcher: failed to add paths: /root
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::filesystem::filesystem_error'
  what():  boost::filesystem::directory_iterator::construct: Permission denied: "/root"
```

I made an alternative approach in 5dd550d, although I was not able to get rid of all duplicate try/catch. Seems to resist the previous failing case. Feel free to merge or patch your approach.
content.html:
Thanks Jackie. I like this much more. Seems like the exists call is not enough to detect all the failing cases:

jrivero@nium build $ GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH="/root" gazebo
QInotifyFileSystemWatcherEngine::addPaths: inotify_add_watch failed: Permission denied
QFileSystemWatcher: failed to add paths: /root
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::filesystem::filesystem_error'
  what():  boost::filesystem::directory_iterator::construct: Permission denied: "/root"

I made an alternative approach in 5dd550d, although I was not able to get rid of all duplicate try/catch. Seems to resist the previous failing case. Feel free to merge or patch your approach.

content.raw: let me know what you think of the most recent update. I think this method could be cleaned up quite a lot further than what I've done here. It functionally works, maybe the log message should be more generalized since I am catching all errors, not just the permission denied one.
content.html: let me know what you think of the most recent update. I think this method could be cleaned up quite a lot further than what I've done here. It functionally works, maybe the log message should be more generalized since I am catching all errors, not just the permission denied one.

content.raw:
This PR has been updated with a complete fix. Couple of caveats:

The fix is Unix-only since I couldn't quite make Boost work for me. I'm going to let @gerkey and @\_jrivero\_ worry about this :)

I have not made a test. It would probably be a unit test for InsertModelWidget.
content.html:
This PR has been updated with a complete fix. Couple of caveats:

The fix is Unix-only since I couldn't quite make Boost work for me. I'm going to let @gerkey and @_jrivero_ worry about this :)

I have not made a test. It would probably be a unit test for InsertModelWidget.

update.description:
Here's a fun bug:

Open up Gazebo on default branch. Point your `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` environment variable to a folder that is readable only by root, or `chmod` something that's already on your `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` so that it's only readable by `root`. Then start Gazebo. It will crash with a message like:
```
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::filesystem::filesystem_error'
  what():  boost::filesystem::status: Permission denied: "/home/jackie/gazebo_models/foo/model.config"
```

I discovered this bug working on the building editor. Some users had folders in their home folder that were owned by root (even worse, a hidden folder, .dbus). The home folder seems like a reasonable default location to leave models, but the problem arose when I tried to add the home folder to the paths displayed in `InsertModelWidget` (the Qt widget that shows the "Insert Model" tab).

This pull request catches the issue by first checking if the user has permission to access a directory before attempting to read it into the Insert Model tab.
update.title: Bugfix for permission denied crash

content.raw: Yep, looks like this is not a complete fix. Tomorrow I will work on a test and a more robust solution.
content.html: Yep, looks like this is not a complete fix. Tomorrow I will work on a test and a more robust solution.

content.raw:
Also, it still crashes by setting my `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` to include a folder of which I couldn't even view the contents (`/var/root` on my mac).
~~~
QKqueueFileSystemWatcherEngine::addPaths: open: Permission denied
QFileSystemWatcher: failed to add paths: /var/root
libc++abi.dylib: terminate called throwing an exception
~~~
Maybe try / catch around `status()`?
content.html:
Also, it still crashes by setting my GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH to include a folder of which I couldn't even view the contents (/var/root on my mac).

QKqueueFileSystemWatcherEngine::addPaths: open: Permission denied
QFileSystemWatcher: failed to add paths: /var/root
libc++abi.dylib: terminate called throwing an exception

Maybe try / catch around status()?

content.raw: It's not working on my mac. All models are giving the "Permission denied" log message and none are showing up in the Insert Model widget.
content.html: It's not working on my mac. All models are giving the "Permission denied" log message and none are showing up in the Insert Model widget.

content.raw: I assume this is `boost::filesystem::status( )`? I wonder why it doesn't need its namespace declared.
content.html: I assume this is boost::filesystem::status( )? I wonder why it doesn't need its namespace declared.
